links.title: The Apple Watch Series 4 Looks Like a Smash Hit
links.description: The Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) Watch line has clearly been a success for the tech giant. In fact, as CEO Tim Cook pointed out during the company's product launch event a few weeks ago, "Apple Watch is not only the No. 1 smartwatch in the world, it's the No. 1 watch, period."

links.title: Benzinga's Bulls & Bears Of The Week: Apple, GE, IBM, Nike, Tesla And More
links.description: Benzinga has featured looks at many investor favorite stocks over the past week. Bullish calls included leaders in e-commerce, smartphones and footwear. Bearish calls included a struggling conglomerate and an electric vehicle leader. Much attention was taken up by the kerfuffle in Washington this past week, but there was also a Federal Reserve rate hike and Elon Musk came under more fire.

links.title: How the tariff wars are already taking some of the steam from US growth
links.description: ChinaFotoPress | Getty Images The tariff wars are showing up in a wider U.S. trade deficit, and have taken some of the steam out of third quarter growth that remains formidable. This week, economists trimmed third quarter growth forecasts, after reports of a wider than expected trade deficit and weaker equipment investment.

links.title: Apple is back above $225: Look who's underwater now | Philip Elmerâ€‘DeWitt
links.description: The first time Apple broke $225, on August 30, all but eight of these analysts were in negative territory. Between the stock's rebound and a flood of post-Labor Day upgrades, the balance of bulls and bears has reverted to something closer to the norm.

messages.body: FAANG Divergence From Broader Market About to Widen http://www.priceactionlab.com/Blog/2018/09/faang-divergence/ $FB $AAPL $AMZN $NFLX $GOOGL

links.title: FAANG Divergence From Broader Market About to Widen
links.description: The wide divergence in the performance of a few tech stocks from the broader market may be a leading indicator of troubles ahead. Year-to date S&P 500 total return is about 10% versus 43% for the equal allocation FAANG portfolio.

links.title: Google May Pay Apple $9 Billion to Remain Default iPhone Search Engine
